q: What is a 'Prototype' in UI/UX design?
o: A simulation of the final product to test interactions and flows

q: Difference between Low-Fidelity and High-Fidelity prototypes?
o: Low-fi focuses on layout/flow (sketchy); High-fi looks/behaves like the final app
Low-fi is for mobile; High-fi is for desktop
Low-fi is black and white only; High-fi is colorful
A static low-fidelity blueprint of the interface structure
A static high-fidelity visual representation of the design
The level of detail and realism (visuals, interactions, content)
A series of static screens linked by hotpots to simulate flow

q: Tool best known for Low-Fidelity 'hand-drawn' style wireframing?

o: Rapid, low-cost iteration and idea validation before digital tools
An interactive area on a screen that triggers an action/navigation when clicked
The relationship between a user input (trigger) and the system's response (action)
The event that initiates an interaction (e.g. Tap, Hover, Drag)
What happens after a trigger (e.g. Navigate, Overlay, Animate)

q: Axure RP is best known for?
o: Complex, logic-driven prototypes with variables and conditional flows

q: Framer is famous for bridging design and...?
Principle (Mac app) is mainly used for?
o: Advanced micro-interactions and complex timeline animations
The path a user takes through the product to accomplish a task
The ideal user journey with no errors or exceptions
A specific condition of a UI element (e.g. Default, Hover, Pressed, Disabled)
The bottom edge of the visible screen area without scrolling
Background moves at a different speed than foreground content creating depth
Content appearing on top of the current screen (e.g. Modal, Tooltip, Menu)
A dialog box that disables the main content until interacted with/dismissed
Designing behavior that adapts to different screen sizes/devices

q: What allows a prototype to feel 'real' without backend code?
o: Micro-interactions, realistic data, and smooth transitions
Placeholder (dummy) text used to fill layouts

q: Why use Real Data vs Lorem Ipsum in prototypes?
o: To test realistic content scaling and emotional impact
Observing real users attempting tasks with the prototype to find issues
Comparing two versions of a design to see which performs better
Visual effect between screen changes (e.g. Slide, Fade, Push)
Automatically interpolating properties of matching layers between frames

q: Which tool created the concept of 'Artboards'?

o: A defined canvas area representing a specific screen or device view
Viewing the prototype on the actual target hardware (phone/tablet) via an app
Transferring design specs, assets, and logic to developers for implementation

q: Tool like Zeplin is used for?

o: Replacing text with unreadable symbols/lines in early low-fi stages
A header that remains fixed at the top while content scrolls beneath
Defining how areas move (Vertical, Horizontal, Fixed) within a viewport
A primary action button that floats above the UI (Material Design)
Three-line icon toggling a side/navigation menu
Large, prominent image at top of a page to grab attention
Secondary nav scheme showing user's location in hierarchy (Home > Category > Item)
Content loads continuously as user scrolls down (e.g. Social Feeds)
Breaking content into discrete pages (1, 2, 3, Next)
Blank version of page structure shown while content is loading (perceived performance)
Small pop-up text label appearing on hover/focus
Process of guiding new users to understand the app's value/features
Consistent vertical spacing and typographic baseline to create visual harmony
Structural framework (columns, gutters) to organize layout
Named entity storing visual design attribute (color, font, spacing) for cross-platform consistency
Methodology breaking UI into Atoms, Molecules, Organisms, Templates, Pages

q: An 'Atom' in Atomic Design refers to?
o: Basic building blocks like Labels, Inputs, Buttons

q: A 'Molecule' in Atomic Design refers to?
o: Groups of atoms functioning together (e.g. Search Form: Input + Button)
High-fidelity sensor-aided prototypes (Voice, Accelerometer, hardware access) without code
Patch-editor logic (nodes) for highly complex interactions/physics
Simple, fast click-through prototyping from images/files
Quickly creating and iterating models to validate ideas fast
Designing for users with disabilities (Color blindness, Screen readers, Motor issues)
Difference in luminance between foreground (text) and background

q: What is 'Tap Target' min recommend size (Apple)?

o: Google's visual design language using light, shadow, and movement
Apple's design guidelines for iOS/macOS apps
Visual clue that indicates how an object should be used (e.g. Button looks clickable)
Mark/Sound that communicates appropriate behavior (e.g. Arrow on a drop-down)
What the user believes about how the system works based on past experience
Users spend most time on other sites; they prefer your site to work the same way as others
Time to acquire a target is function of distance to and size of target (Big/Close is fast)
Time to make a decision increases with the number/complexity of choices
Average person can keep 7 (plus/minus 2) items in working memory
Psychological laws describing how humans group similar elements and recognize patterns
Elements close together are perceived as related
Elements looking similar (color, shape) are perceived as same group
Brain fills in missing parts of a design to create a whole image
Empty space between elements to reduce clutter and improve readability
Arrangement of elements to show importance (Size, Color, Position)
Button/Link prompting immediate response (e.g. 'Sign Up Now')
Crafting copy for UI (Microcopy) to guide users (labels, errors, buttons)
Small bits of text (button labels, hints) that aid user interaction
UI trickery designed to make users do things they didn't intend (e.g. hard to unsubscribe)
Building for modern browsers but ensuring basic functionality on older ones
Starting with basic core content/functionality and adding layer of improvements (JS/CSS) for capable browsers
Fictional character representing a user type to guide design decisions
Visualizing the user's process to accomplish a goal over time/channels
Visual tool capturing what user Says, Thinks, Does, Feels
Method to help design information architecture by asking users to group topics
Expert review of interface against established usability principles (heuristics)
Mental effort required to learn/use the interface
Applying game mechanics (points, badges) to non-game contexts to engage users
Design concept mimicking real-world objects/textures (e.g. Leather calendar)
Minimalist UI style without stylistic elements like shadows/gradients/textures
Visual style combining flat design and skeuomorphism using soft shadows to create depth
UI trend emphasizing transparency and background blur (frosted glass effect)
Web design approach that makes pages render well on a variety of devices/window sizes
Layout using percentages rather than fixed pixels for widths
Creating distinct layouts for specific screen sizes (served based on device)
Designing for the smallest screen (mobile) before scaling up to desktop

q: What is 'Responsive Resize' in Adobe XD?
o: Feature that automatically adjusts group layout/constraints when resizing logic suggests it

q: Which tool introduced 'Auto Layout' as a major layout engine?

o: Layer names and hierarchy matching between frames
A specific occurrence (Mouse Up, Mouse Down, Double Click) that can trigger logic

q: What is 'Condition' in advanced prototyping (e.g. Axure)?
o: A logic check (If X is true) required before an action runs
A container with multiple states/views used for carousels, toggles, and advanced interactivity
Timeline controlled by a property change (e.g. scroll position drives animation)
Grouping related components (Button Primary, Secondary) to simplify switching in instances
Component that contains its own interaction logic (e.g. Checkbox toggles itself) independent of the page
The source definition; changes here propagate to all instances
A copy of the Master Component that can have overrides but follows master structure
Changing specific properties (Text, Image, Color) on an instance without affecting the Master
Breaking the link to the Master Component, turning it into a regular frame/group
Rules defining how an object behaves when its parent is resized (e.g. Pin Left, Pin Top)
Column is vertical divisions; Modular is loose rows and columns forming modules
Horizontal lines (usually 4px or 8px) for aligning text baselines
Designing using multiples of 8 (8, 16, 24, 32) for spacing and sizing
Scales cleanly across most screen resolutions (divisible by 8, 4, 2)
The visible area of a web page/app on a specific device screen
Pixel width points where layout changes to adapt (e.g. 768px for tablet)
Writing default styles for mobile, then using min-width media queries for larger screens
Writing default styles for desktop, using max-width queries for smaller screens
Touch target is the clickable area (invisible padding); Visual target is the icon/text seen
The area on a mobile screen easily reachable by the user's thumb when holding one-handed
Newspaper industry (top half of folded paper on newsstand)
Old theory that users stop using a site if they can't find content in 3 clicks (largely debunked, ease matters more than count)
Showing design for 5 seconds to test immediate impression and clarity
Low-cost, impromptu user testing (e.g. asking strangers in a cafe)
Technology measuring where users look and for how long (Heatmaps, Gaze plots)
Visual representation of data showing hot (high interaction) vs cold areas
Shows how far down the page users typically scroll
Shows individual clicks as dots on the interface
User interacts with interface that is manually operated by a hidden human (simulating AI/System)
Testing the site structure (IA) efficiency without visual bias (simplified text hierarchy)
Lightness or Darkness of a color
The color family name (Red, Blue, Green, etc.)
Three colors evenly spaced on the color wheel
Colors opposite each other on the color wheel
Colors next to each other on the color wheel
Variations (Shades, Tints, Tones) of a single hue
Art/technique of arranging type to make written language legible and appealing
Fonts with small decorative strokes (feet) at the ends of characters (e.g. Times New Roman)
Fonts without decorative strokes (clean lines) (e.g. Arial, Roboto)
Adjustment of space between specific pairs of characters
Overall spacing between all characters in a block of text
Vertical space between lines of text

q: Best practice for Body Text width (measure)?

o: A single word or short line left alone at the end of a paragraph/column
A single word/line at start of new column/page
Using the OS default font (SF Pro, Segoe UI, Roboto) for performance
Fonts installed on most operating systems (Arial, Times, Verdana)
Font file downloaded by browser to render custom typography
Visual language using symbols/icons to represent functionality
Scalable Vector Graphics (XML based, resolution independent)
Scale without quality loss, small file size, code editable
Small icon displayed in browser tab (16x16 or 32x32)
Collection of reusable components, guidelines, and standards for building products
Document defining visual styles (Colors, Typography, Usage) for brand consistency
Collection of UI patterns/components (e.g. Navigation, Forms, Cards)

q: Difference: Design System vs Pattern Library?
o: Design System includes principles, voice, guidelines AND the pattern library (Holistic)
Coining term 'User Experience', Design of Everyday Things
A door design that confuses users about whether to push or pull (Bad affordance)
Discover, Define, Develop, Deliver (Diverge and Converge thinking)
Synthesizing insights, framing the problem statement (Converge)
Minimum Viable Product (Smallest version releasing value to learn from)

q: What is 'Agile' in context of UX?
o: Iterative development with frequent release/feedback cycles
Sequential design process (Research -> Design -> Code -> Test) without iteration loops
A 5-day process to answer critical business questions through design, prototyping, and testing
Using sticky dots to vote on features/ideas on a whiteboard
Collage of images/text to define visual style/direction
Visual sequence (comic strip) illustrating user context/scenario
Structural design of shared information environments (organizing content)
Hierarchical diagram showing structure of pages in a site
Menu available on every page (usually top header)
Pros: Saves space. Cons: Low discoverability/efficiency
Expandable menu displaying many options in 2D layout (columns)
Menu hidden off-screen that slides in when triggered
Footer that stays at bottom of viewport or content (whichever is lower)
Multiplane scrolling where layers move at different speeds
JSON-based animation file format (Airbnb) for vector animations
Tool for creating interactive vector animations/state machines for runtime
Version control hub for Sketch files (Git for designers)

q: What is 'Version History' in modern design tools?
o: Automatically saving file states over time, allowing revert/view of past versions
A parallel version of the file for exploring changes without affecting the main file
Combining changes from a branch back into the main file
When two people edited the same layer/property, requiring a decision on which to keep
Process of delivering specs (measurements, assets, tokens) to engineering
Old term for annotated specs showing dimensions/spacing (often red lines)
View in design tools allowing devs to click elements and see CSS/Code properties

Configuration for file format, scale (@1x, @2x), and naming of assets

Android unit of measurement independent of screen density (approx 160dpi baseline)
Apple's abstract unit of measurement (1pt = 1px on standard, 2px on Retina @2x)
Root EM: Size relative to the root element's (html) font-size
Size relative to the parent element's font-size
Hexadecimal representation of RGB color values
The component of a color defining its transparency/opacity
Gradual blending between two or more colors (Linear, Radial, Angular)
Mathematical formula used for drawing smooth vector curves via control points
Controls extended from anchor points to adjust curve curvature
Combining shapes using logic: Union, Subtract, Intersect, Exclude
Combining two shapes into one silhouette
Removing the top shape area from the bottom shape
Keeping only the overlapping area of two shapes
Keeping non-overlapping areas (hollows out the intersection)
Destructively merging layers/paths into a single vector path
Converting a path's specific stroke width into a filled shape geometry
Using a shape to hide/reveal parts of another layer (Clipping)
Using transparency levels to determine visibility (White=Visible, Black=Hidden)

o: CSS property controlling the vertical stacking order (which element is on top)
CSS concept: Content + Padding + Border + Margin
Space INSIDE the element (between content and border)
Space OUTSIDE the element (between border and neighbors)

CSS Layout system for 2-dimensional layouts (rows and columns)
Element removed from normal document flow and positioned relative to nearest positioned ancestor
Element positioned relative to the browser window (viewport); stays when scrolling
Element positioned relative to its normal position in the flow
Element toggles between relative and fixed depending on scroll position
Real content, or 'Corporate Ipsum', 'Bacon Ipsum', etc.

Description of an image for screen readers or when image fails to load
Accessible Rich Internet Applications (attributes to improve a11y)
Visual indicator (outline) showing which element currently has keyboard input focus
Style change when mouse cursor is over an element
Style during the moment a button is being clicked/tapped
Element is visible but non-interactive (often grayed out)
Screen design for when there is no data to display (e.g. Empty Inbox, No Search Results)
Feedback showing an action completed correctly (Green checkmark, toast)
Feedback showing something went wrong (Red outline, message)
Feedback showing process is ongoing (Spinner, Skeleton, Progress bar)
Small, non-modal message briefly appearing (usually at bottom/top) then disappearing
Similar to toast, but can contain a single action (e.g. Undo) and is mainly bottom-aligned
Modal requires interaction/dismissal before engaging background; Non-modal allows parallel interaction
Modal window displaying an image/content while dimming the background
Vertically stacked list of headers that expand/collapse content sections
Navigation pattern allowing switching between different views in the same context
Pagination offers control/location; Infinite Scroll offers discovery/engagement
Control to switch between two states (On/Off)
Selection control allowing multiple options to be selected
Selection control allowing only ONE option to be selected from a set
Control to select a value from a range by dragging a handle
Interactive calendar component for selecting dates
Control to increase/decrease value by fixed amount (+/- steps) OR Progress indicator for multi-step forms
Step-by-step process used to guide users through complex tasks (e.g. Installation)
Overview screen displaying key metrics, data visualizations, and quick actions
Standalone web page created for a marketing campaign/specific goal (conversion)
Sequence of screens helping new users set up and learn the app
To delight, inform, and guide the user on how to populate the screen (call to action)
Reduce perceived wait time by showing layout structure before data arrives
Error page shown when a requested URL is not found
Friendly message, helpful links to Home or Search, brand personality
Cues (labels, images) that give users confidence they are holding the right path to their goal
Users continuously ignore page elements they perceive (correctly or not) to be ads
Myth that users don't scroll. Reality: Users scroll if content is engaging/cued.
Hides navigation options, increasing interaction cost and lowering discovery
Low engagement on slides beyond the first; users often ignore them (banner blindness)
Can cause motion sickness, accessibility issues, and performance lag
Quantifiable measure used to track and assess the status of a specific process (e.g. Task success rate)
Key Performance Indicator (Critical metrics for business success)
Percentage of users who take a desired action (e.g. Buy, Sign up)
Percentage of visitors who navigate away from the site after viewing only one page
Percentage of users who continue to use the product over a given period
Percentage of subscribers who discontinue their subscription within a specific period
Rigorous evaluation of a product's compliance with accessibility standards (WCAG)
A storage container for a value (text/number) accessible across all pages/scenes
Variable accessible only within a specific scope (e.g. a single page or component)

o: Carrying a user's name or total cart price from one screen to another
Interface to create logic statements (If Text on Widget A equals 'Password' Show Widget B)
A dataset-driven list where modifying one item updates layout for all items in the list
A formula used to calculate a value (e.g. [[Item.Price * Item.Quantity]])
Linking property changes of one layer to another (e.g. Scroll Y controls Header Opacity)
Triggering actions when a property value enters/leaves a specific numerical range
Watching for a specific change in any property (e.g. Detect when Opacity becomes 0)
Communication mechanism between different components or even different devices (Bridge)
Simulating voice commands (VUI) and responses (Speech-to-Text / Text-to-Speech)
Space (empty columns) before a column starts
Aligning elements based on how they LOOK centered/aligned rather than mathematical bounds

q: Why Optical Alignment for 'Play' triangle icon?
o: Geometric center usually looks off-center due to uneven visual weight; needs shifting right
Curved letters (O, C) extend slightly above/below baseline/cap-height to look same size as flat letters
The dot above the lowercase 'i' or 'j'
Two or more letters combined into a single glyph (e.g. fi, fl)
Curved quotation marks (typographically correct) vs straight ticks (programming)
Punctuation marks placed outside the alignment edge to maintain a clean vertical line
Usually base line-height (e.g. 24px) that all vertical spacing is a multiple of
Height of a capital letter above the baseline
Part of a letter extending below the baseline (g, y, p)
Part of a lowercase letter extending above x-height (h, t, l)
Single font file containing multiple variations (weight, width, slant) on an axis

What is 'Color Contrast' minimum for AA (Large Text)?
How to design for Color Blindness?
o: Don't rely on color alone to convey meaning (use icons, labels, patterns)
The sequence in which interactive elements receive focus (Tab key navigation)
Hidden link at top of page allowing keyboard users to jump past nav to main content
Provides meaning/structure to content (Header, Main, Nav) for browsers/assistive tech
Major page sections (banner, main, navigation) identified for screen reader navigation
Rate of change of a parameter over time (Slow start, fast middle, slow end)
Constant speed from start to finish (feels robotic/unnatural)
Starts fast, decelerates (good for entrances, feels natural)
Slow start, fast middle, slow end (Standard curve)
Physics-based animation defined by stiffness, damping, mass (bouncy feel)

q: Disney Principle: 'Squash and Stretch' in UI?
o: Giving objects weight/flexibility (e.g. button flattening slightly on press)
Preparing the viewer for an action (e.g. button shrinking before expanding)
Directing attention to the most important element effectively
Termination of an action (e.g. list bounces past end then settles)
Visual/Auditory/Haptic response confirming the trigger was received
Tactile vibration response from the device
Makes load times feel shorter by showing progress/intent vs blank screen
Revealing information/features only when needed to reduce clutter/cognitive load
Breaking content into small, distinct units (e.g. Phone number groups) for easier memory
Elements sharing a clearly defined area (background/border) are perceived as a group
Elements connected by visual properties (lines) are perceived as related
Users judge an experience largely based on its peak (intense point) and its end
People remember uncompleted/interrupted tasks better than completed ones
Item that stands out directly (differs from rest) is most likely to be remembered (CTA button)
Users best remember the first and last items in a series (Primacy/Recency)
Users perceive attractive designs as more usable/tolerable of errors
Productivity soars when computer and user interact at a pace (<400ms) ensuring neither waits
Simplest solution is usually the correct one; avoid unnecessary complexity
80% of effects come from 20% of causes (e.g. 80% usage is on 20% of features)
Be liberal in what you accept, and conservative in what you send (Forms)
Every system has a certain amount of complexity that cannot be removed, only shifted (to dev or user)
Tendency to approach a goal more quickly as one gets closer to it (Progress bars)
Psychological phenomenon where people copy actions of others (Reviews, Testimonials)
Perceived value increases as availability decreases ('Only 2 left!')
People prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains (Fear of missing out)
Reliance on the first piece of information offered (the 'anchor') when making decisions (Pricing)
Tendency to search for/interpret info in a way that confirms one's preconceptions

q: What is 'Survivorship Bias' in UX research?
o: Focusing on users who 'survived' the process (successful) and ignoring those who dropped out
Continuing a failing course of action because of resources already invested
Users value products more highly if they helped create/assemble them
People ascribe more value to things merely because they own them
Decisions influenced by how options are presented (Positive vs Negative frame)
Difficulty making a decision when faced with too many options (Paralysis)
Learned behavior to ignore standard ad locations and visual styles
Failure to notice changes in visual stimulus (e.g. subtle UI upate)
Obligation to give back when something is received (Free ebook -> Email sign up)
Tendency to obey/trust figures of authority or expertise (Badges, Endorsements)
People like to be consistent with things they have previously said or done
People are more likely to say yes to requests from people they like/relate to
New feature allowing reusable values for colors, numbers, strings, and booleans across design
Different contexts for variable values (e.g. Light Mode vs Dark Mode)

q: What is 'String Interpolation' in Figma Variables?
o: Inserting a variable value into a text string dynamically (e.g. 'Hello, [User]')
Toggle switch in the instance inspector to turn a layer visibility on/off
Allowing value of an instance (e.g. Icon) to be swapped from a dropdown menu in the Inspector
Using a placeholder component (0px frame) intended to be swapped with actual content in instances
W3C Design Token Community Group (ongoing spec, usually JSON based)
Documentation platform for design systems, syncing with Figma/Sketch/Code
Frontend tool for building UI components/pages in isolation (Documentation & Testing)
Visual testing tool ensuring UI components don't change unexpectedly (Regression testing)
Verifying that recent changes haven't broken existing functionality/visuals
Test that sometimes passes and sometimes fails without code changes (unreliable)
Inputting invalid, unexpected, or random data to crash the interface or find bugs
Uses real data, responsive by default, closest to final product (truth)
Empowers designers to build complex logic without engineering dependency
Web app that uses modern web capabilities to deliver an app-like experience (Offline, Push)
App built specifically for a mobile OS (iOS/Android) using platform-specific languages (Swift/Kotlin)
Write code once, deploy to multiple platforms (iOS, Android, Web)
Responsive flows fluidly; Adaptive snaps to fixed layouts for specific devices
Ratio between physical pixels and logical (CSS) pixels (e.g. 2.0 for Retina)
Technique to increase apparent resolution by manipulating RGB sub-pixels (text smoothing)
Instructions in font file to align vector outlines to screen grid for legibility at small sizes
Flash of Unstyled Content (content appears before CSS loads)
Flash of Unstyled Text (fallback font shown before web font loads)

Time it takes for the main content of the page to load
Time from when a user first interacts (click) to when browser responds
New Core Web Vital replacing FID; measures responsiveness to all interactions
Deferring loading of non-critical resources (images below fold) until needed
Loading resources immediately as soon as code is parsed
Simulating slower network speeds (3G, Offline) to test performance
Removing unused code from the final bundle to reduce file size
Removing whitespace/comments and renaming variables to shorten code for production
Scripting language extending CSS with variables, nesting, and mixins
Block Element Modifier (Naming convention for CSS classes)
Object Oriented CSS (Separating structure from skin)
Scalable and Modular Architecture for CSS (Categorization of rules)
Using single-purpose utility classes (e.g. .text-center, .mt-4) to build UI

Model for managing branches (Master, Develop, Feature branches) in a project

Software delivery practice where code changes are automatically prepared and released to production
As a [user], I want [goal] so that [benefit]
Conditions that a software product must satisfy to be accepted by a user/customer
Framework focusing on the job the customer is hiring the product to do

Visibility of system status (Keep user informed)

Recognition rather than recall (Minimize memory load)
Flexibility and efficiency of use (Accelerators for experts)

Help users recognize, diagnose, and recover from errors (Plain language)
Help and documentation (Easy to search, focused on tasks)

Software with source code available for anyone to inspect, modify, and enhance

Legal right granting creator of original work exclusive rights to its use
Focusing on visual layout without being distracted by readable content
Use of nonsense text (often pseudo-Latin) to fill space; 'It's all Greek to me'
Kerning is space between TWO letters; Tracking is space over a RANGE of letters

Invisible line typically at the top of lowercase letters (x-height)
